notesStmt.note: I have chosen my definition and categorization of “marxist rhetoric” based on James Martin's 2022 article “Marx's Rhetoric,” featured in the Goldsmiths Research online repository. I focus on his detailed explanation of the rhetoric of criticism, dynamics of class politics, and rhetoric of critical political economy. I often choose to mark phrases that read as “call to actions,” as Martin claims that Marx sought to urge the working class to become forces of social and political change. I also zone in on themes of martyrdom, that seem to align themselves with critiquing the governing classes while lauding the sacrifices of the lower (or change-making) classes.

lg.l: Frederick II was emperor of the high-and-mightyGermans and yet

l.interp: he was excommunicated by the Pope

lg.l: because he made the study of medicine a requisite for doctors
before they could prescribe infusions for a fee
or cut off flesh from a person's flesh.

l.interp: Miguel Servet was excommunicated shortly before

lg.l: they say this was to speed it up for him
to go on discussing the advanced sciences in restful eternity.
Martin Lutherbbelieved God the Father's divine liver acted up
whenever he looked through the clouds and saw fat priests
city neighborhoods getting rich from the sale of indulgences
He was thrown out of the Churchfor defending God's liver
Thin, puny, with wary eye and down-trodden look,
I'd have to perform marvelous actions like theirs
to be also thrown out of the Church
and save my artless vanity forever.

body.note: Marx often critiqued class issues, namely to do with property relations. Dalton refers to the "high and mighty" Germans, who were a foremost military and world power during Frederick II's reign. Dalton here recognizes the downfall of powerful structures, even ones on a national scale,like the Catholic church. He also betrays a level of atheism inherent in Marxism as he criticized the Pope's dictator-like power to abide by religion over science.

Dalton seems to be laying out the consequences for class/political hierarchies. Power structures do not easily allow a change of the status quo, even if that change is clearly for the better of the masses.
Another instance of a significant member of the "logical" sciences, creating something to better the masses, and being punished for it.

This is another example of class politics rhetoric, specifically referring to areas near cities that profit off urban resources and centrality, without engaging with the downfalls and poverties of urban life.
Another appeal against organized religion in comparison to his list of martyrs..
